moves.1... e6: Unusual reply, blocks in bishop on c8.
moves.2... d5 3. Bd3 a6: This doesn't do anything, better to develop.
moves.4. Bf4 c5: Threatens my other pawn, offering a swap.
moves.7. Ngf3: In a castling position. Notice that my opponent has not developed any of his kingside pieces.
moves.7... c4 8. Bc2 b5 9. O-O h6: Again, this does nothing, should be opening up kingside pieces.
moves.10. Qe2: I protect the pawn with my queen in order to play b3.
moves.10... Nf6: Finally, my opponent develops his queenside knight.
moves.11. e5: But, as it is already the middle game, the knight is vulnerable and open to threats.
moves.13. a3 a4: Two advanced pieces, this could cause trouble.
moves.14. Qd1: Wanting to threaten the knight with Qb1.
moves.15... Nf8 16. h3 Bg5: I didn't understand this move, maybe wanting to expose my kingside flank after 17. Bxg5 hxg5 18. ???? g4.
moves.17. Bxg5 hxg5 18. Re1 Qe7: Wanting to castle queenside, the kingside is dangerous with the h-pawn gone.
moves.19. Kf1 O-O-O 20. Ng1: Wanting to play g4 to stop my opponent playing g4, I protect the h-pawn.
moves.21. hxg4 Rh1: My knight is pinned to my king.
moves.22... Qh4: Can't play it anymore, and my opponent is threatening Qh2.
moves.23. Ndf3: I threaten the queen and stop my opponent from playing Qh2.
moves.23... Qxg4 24. Bd1 Qe4:
Now, the mistake! My opponent said he accidently played his queen one square too far. But this is not a fatal mistake, he will be -5 down, but its possible to come back from there. One of my friends won a game when he was -14 down, although the two players weren't very good. :)

1. a3 d5 2. b3 b5 3. f4 e6 4. c3 Qh4+ 5. g3 Qd8 6. g4 Bb7 7. b4 d4 8. cxd4 Qxd4 9. Nf3 Qxa1 10. e3 Qxb1 11. Bxb5+ c6 12. Ne5 cxb5 13. h4 Bxh1 14. Kf2 Na6 15. Kg1 Qe4 16. Qf1 Rc8 17. Qxb5+ Kd8 18. Qd7# 1-0

It was quite a pathetic game.
moves.26... Ng6 27. Nxf7 Rf8: Threatens my knight, but I can still check the king and win a pawn.
moves.28. Nd6+ Kc7 29. Nxb5+: Free pawn, checks the king again.
moves.35. c5+ Kc7 36. Nb5+: I made a mistake as well, not seeing or forgetting about the knight on c3, I accidently suicide my knight.
moves.38. Qc2: I protect the  bishop and threaten the knight.
moves.38... Nxa4 39. Qxa4 Nxd4: Free pawn and threatens my queen.
moves.40. Qa7+ Kc6 41. Qb6+ Kd5 42. Qd6+: I am checking the king repeatedly.
moves.42... Ke4 43. Re1+: Instead of taking the rook right away, I decide to check the king again.
moves.43... Kf5: I think Kd3 would've been better.
moves.44. Qxf8+: I capture the rook, and yet again, check the king.
moves.44... Kg6: Now I can't check the king again!
moves.48. Ke2:
Wanting to get out my knight, I move my king out of the way of the pin and he resigns.
Jekingsr could've come back, but kind of gave up after losing his queen, so never give up.
As long your alive, there's always a chance, says Jack West Jr.

gameName: As Long As You're Alive, There's Always a Chance
